moves.1. d4 d5 2. Bf4 Nc6 3. e3 Nf6 4. Nf3 Bf5: Black looks to open his black bishop and break the tension.
Na4 avoids 13. ...Qxb5? 14. Nxb5 ... 15. Nxc7 forking Black's rook and queen pawn gaining a pawn.
moves.14. e6 Bxe6: Who says there's no such thing as a free pawn for lunch?
moves.15. Nxe6 Qxb5: Qxb5 is better now that Black's bishop's diagonal is clear.
moves.16. Bxb5 Nxb2 17. Rxd5 fxe6 18. Rd7 c6: protects Black's queen bishop pawn and attacks White's light bishop.
moves.19. Be2 Rf7: protects b7 and prepares rooks for doubling later
moves.20. Rxf7 Kxf7 21. c3 Bxc3: Still eating at the "All the free pawns you can eat" seafood buffet.
Black hangs his queen's knight pawn.
moves.27. Bxb5 Nb6 28. Bc6 c4+ 29. Kc2 Nxd7 30: protects Black's king's knight pawn and effectively hides from both White's bishops.
moves.33. h4: The beginning of the end.  Using the Point Count, White has a point for the bishop pair and another for the off-side majority ( 2 p.c.).  Black has a point for the passed pawn, another because it is advanced and another for better king position ( 3 p.c.).  This is just the static picture, however, as h4 causes White's king's knight pawn to become backward with...
moves.33... Be1 34. Bd8 Nd5: Bxd5 trades even material and connects two of Black's isolani.
moves.35. g4 Nxe3+ 36. Kb1 hxg4 37. fxg4 Nxg4: In just four moves, Black has gained two pawns ( 6 p.c.) by checking the king before re-capturing.
moves.39... Bxh4 40. Be2 c3 41. Bd6 c2+ 42. Kc: Black has a won game.  White's sole pawn is backward (-1 p.c.) and Black's bishop and pawn on the a-file are invincible since neither White's king nor light bishop can touch them.  Black is up 5 pawns ( 15 p.c.) putting Black more than 16 points in the lead.
